aspects.why_is_it_important: Not only can your domain be blacklisted, but the IP address from which you send your emails can as well. If this "Mail Server IP" is blacklisted it can cause your messages to be rejected or flagged as spam. It is important to get delisted and identify the root cause of why you were listed.If you use any tools/softwares to send out emails, it is possible that the shared or dedicated IP address being used by these is on a blacklist. Certain blacklists can have a severe affect on the ability to reach the inbox. We have aggregated a list of ones known to be meaningful.
aspects.message: Your Mail Server IP address is listed on significant blacklists.

factors.name: "From" IP Address Blacklists
factors.title: The Mail Server IP "149.72.131.227" that your email was sent from is listed on 1 significant blacklist(s). This test does not necessarily take specific whitelists into consideration.
factors.solution:
Many blacklists allow you to make a removal request. Visit these URLs to read about and potentially make a removal request for your domain.
Blacklist: dnsbl-3.uceprotect.net
Review at: http://www.uceprotect.net/en/index.php


NOTE: If you know you are on this whitelist you can likely ignore this failure, but double checking can't hurt. If you are using a shared IP address it may become blacklisted again as other senders using this IP address can get it re-blacklisted. On the other hand if you are using a dedicated IP address and cannot get it delisted, then you should switch to a new dedicated IP address or a shared IP address.
factors.passing_description: The "from" IP address is not listed on any impactful blacklists.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Without having a Requested Mail Receiver DMARC policy published, emails from your domain can be spoofed and sent on your behalf.
aspects.message: Your DMARC authentication is not setup using best practices.

factors.name: DKIM Signature and From Domain Alignment
factors.title: Your "from" domain does not match your DKIM "from" domain or does not have DKIM signing.
factors.solution:
Make sure your DKIM authentication is setup correctly so your DKIM domain matches the from address in your emails.

Your From domain is: gmail.com
Your DKIM domain(s): sendgrid.net

Existing DKIM Signature Header:
Version: 1
Domain: sendgrid.net
Algorithm: rsa-sha256
Algorithm_type: relaxed/relaxed
Selector: smtpapi

NOTE: To pass Authenticated Received Chain (ARC) email authentication, Email Service Providers will check for the alignment of both DKIM and SPF to the From header, but only 1 of the above needs to be aligned for the check to pass. It is still best practice to have both aligned for redundancy, so if anything errors when checking either DKIM or SPF the other can still succeed and your email will not be marked as unauthenticated.
factors.passing_description: The email "from" domain matches the DKIM signature "from" domain.

factors.name: SPF From Address and From Address Alignment
factors.title: Your "from" address does not match your SPF "from" address.
factors.solution:
Make sure your SPF authentication is setup correctly so your SPF from domain matches the from domain in your emails.

Your From domain is: gmail.com
Your SPF MailFrom domain is: sendgrid.net

Existing SPF header attributes:
Status: pass
Message: sendgrid.net: 149.72.131.227 is authorized to use 'bounces+24653094-eac9-test-palani=test.mailgenius.com@sendgrid.net' in 'mfrom' identity (mechanism 'ip4:149.72.0.0/16' matched)
Receiver: p-pm-inbound02c-aws-useast1c
Identity: mailfrom
Envelope-from: bounces+24653094-eac9-test-palani=test.mailgenius.com@sendgrid.net
Helo: wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net
Client-ip: 149.72.131.227


NOTE: To pass Authenticated Received Chain (ARC) email authentication, Email Service Providers will check for the alignment of both DKIM and SPF to the From header, but only 1 of the above needs to be aligned for the check to pass. It is still best practice to have both aligned for redundancy, so if anything errors when checking either DKIM or SPF the other can still succeed and your email will not be marked as unauthenticated.
factors.passing_description: The email "from" address matches the SPF "from" address.

factors.name: Existing DMARC DNS Record
factors.title: No TXT DMARC record, using the specified "_dmarc" subdomain, is published.
factors.solution:
Publish a TXT DMARC record at:
_dmarc.gmail.com

It should include at least the version (v=DMARC1) and the appropriate policy, represented by the p= tag, for your domain.
factors.passing_description: There is a DMARC DNS record for the appropriate domain.

factors.name: DMARC Version Tag
factors.title: Your DMARC record does not include a valid version.
factors.solution:
Update your DMARC record to start with v=DMARC1 and remove any other references to a DMARC version.

Existing DNS Records:
_dmarc.gmail.com. 600 IN TXT v=DMARC1; p=none; sp=quarantine; rua=mailto:mailauth-reports@google.com


Note: You can only edit these records when sending from a custom domain.
factors.passing_description: The DMARC DNS record starts with a valid version tag.

factors.name: DMARC Policy Tag
factors.title: Your DMARC record does not include a valid policy.
factors.solution:
Update your DMARC record to include p=your policy here. The policy can be one of none, quarantine, or reject.

Existing DNS Records:
_dmarc.gmail.com. 600 IN TXT v=DMARC1; p=none; sp=quarantine; rua=mailto:mailauth-reports@google.com


Note: You can only edit these records when sending from a custom domain.
factors.passing_description: The DMARC DNS record includes a valid policy tag.

factors.name: Duplicate DMARC DNS Records
factors.title: There are multiple DMARC records published.
factors.solution:
Delete all but one DMARC record and ensure the remaining DMARC record is properly updated with a valid version (v=DMARC1) and policy.

Existing DNS Records:
_dmarc.gmail.com. 600 IN TXT v=DMARC1; p=none; sp=quarantine; rua=mailto:mailauth-reports@google.com
factors.passing_description: There are no duplicate DMARC DNS records for the specified domain.

factors.name: DMARC None Policy
factors.title: Your DMARC record policy is set to "none".
factors.solution:
You may want to set your DMARC record to have a policy of reject or quarantine. A policy of none results in no action when an email from your domain fails the DMARC mechanism, allowing spoofers to act more freely.

Before making this change it is important to understand that a policy other than none can result in legitimate email being sent to spam. If anyone sending from this domain fails an Email Service Provider's DMARC check, only a none policy will allow the mail to reach to the inbox. This also includes anyone who is fraudulently sending from this domain. This is why it is important to make sure your DMARC, DKIM, & SPF authentication is properly setup for all senders of your domain including all email tools you are using before employing a stricter policy of either reject or quarantine.

Existing DNS Records:
_dmarc.gmail.com. 600 IN TXT v=DMARC1; p=none; sp=quarantine; rua=mailto:mailauth-reports@google.com


Note: You can only edit these records when sending from a custom domain.
factors.passing_description: The DMARC DNS record is set to a valid policy that is more strict than "none".

aspects.why_is_it_important: Having a blacklisted link in your email body can cause your message to be flagged as spam or rejected.
aspects.message: Your email body includes links that are on significant blacklists.

factors.name: HTML Body Domains Blacklists
factors.title: Your email body includes 1 blacklisted link(s). This test does not necessarily take specific whitelists into consideration.
factors.passing_description: No linked domains within the HTML body are listed on any impactful blacklists.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Your HTML body has a significant impact on whether or not your email will be marked as spam. HTML is parsed and evaluated by Email Service Providers to determine if it is following best practices that are favorably viewed when inboxing.
aspects.message: Your message body is not following best practices.

factors.name: Spammy Language
factors.title: Your email includes phrases that are commonly flagged as spam.
factors.solution:
Remove any language referring to:
guarantees, dear friend/winner/etc., strong buy, stock opportunities, investment advisor/advice, non-accredited universities, male or body enhancement, impotence, urgent buy/business/notice/reply/request/etc., money back/compensation, free quote, bad credit, losing weight without exercise, financial freedom, marketing partners, unclaimed accounts or money, acting now, stronger sex drive, porn, affordable prices, make you bucks/money/hundreds/thousands/etc., lottery winner/ticket/payout/etc., online pharmacy, advance fee, inheritance, prescription drugs etc.
factors.passing_description: The message body does not contain many of the common spam phrases.

factors.name: Linked Image
factors.title: Your HTML body is short and includes a linked image.
factors.passing_description: The HTML body does not contain a linked image or the rest of the HTML body is large enough to render the linked image unsuspicious.

factors.name: Text to Image Ratio
factors.title: Your email body has a low ratio of text to image area.
factors.solution:
Your message has been flagged with a low ratio of text to image area, which is positively correlated to spam messages. Use a higher mix of text to images in your HTML body and try to avoid using images over text to represent your written message.

Spam filters may detect:

<img align="center" border="0" src="https://cdn.templates.unlayer.com/assets/1606906849237-logo.png" alt="Image" title="Image" style="outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;clear: both;display: inline-block !important;border: none;height: auto;float: none;width: 77%;max-width: 138.6px;" width="138.6" class="v-src-width v-src-max-width">


<img align="center" border="0" src="https://cdn.templates.unlayer.com/assets/1606934810497-02.png" alt="Image" title="Image" style="outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;clear: both;display: inline-block !important;border: none;height: auto;float: none;width: 100%;max-width: 280px;" width="280" class="v-src-width v-src-max-width">


<img align="center" border="0" src="https://cdn.templates.unlayer.com/assets/1606932761674-2.jpg" alt="Image" title="Image" style="outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;clear: both;display: inline-block !important;border: none;height: auto;float: none;width: 100%;max-width: 280px;" width="280" class="v-src-width v-src-max-width">


<img src="https://cdn.tools.unlayer.com/social/icons/circle-white/facebook.png" alt="Facebook" title="Facebook" width="32" style="outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;clear: both;display: block !important;border: none;height: auto;float: none;max-width: 32px !important">


<img src="https://cdn.tools.unlayer.com/social/icons/circle-white/instagram.png" alt="Instagram" title="Instagram" width="32" style="outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;clear: both;display: block !important;border: none;height: auto;float: none;max-width: 32px !important">


<img src="https://cdn.tools.unlayer.com/social/icons/circle-white/twitter.png" alt="Twitter" title="Twitter" width="32" style="outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;clear: both;display: block !important;border: none;height: auto;float: none;max-width: 32px !important">


<img src="https://u24653094.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/open?upn=jKu1usnTEY3IPCVH65vmH23tzMI5MeeO9pBlEwGPWw0uDzv3YVwyIleGVPBESNOqHpTj8Q3Rpif37m8opNjSOytFEqCwrRfXuKzkCrZyW75GkWtTfP5jU8hAGUFIvlhk7qhdg6PzhacU-2BFCoZFI5bBGUOUpJxBLa-2BdKQVOAjbT-2FwUJETGy6lLoJ4IAfHjL4yZbuyLcBrbR2O5iedLwSS2V6ijS7IlS2oojMIy-2FegOWM-3D" alt="" width="1" height="1" border="0" style="height:1px !important;width:1px !important;border-width:0 !important;margin-top:0 !important;margin-bottom:0 !important;margin-right:0 !important;margin-left:0 !important;padding-top:0 !important;padding-bottom:0 !important;padding-right:0 !important;padding-left:0 !important;">
factors.passing_description: The HTML body text to image ratio is high enough to be unlike what is commonly found in spam messages.

factors.name: Obfuscated Text
factors.title: Your email body includes obfuscated text.
factors.solution: Do not use HTML and/or CSS to hide content in your message body. Doing this may cause emails to be marked as spam. Also look for and remove any encodings (hex, ASCII, etc.) that may be obfuscating any text. Your message has been flagged as having 5% or more obfuscated HTML.
factors.passing_description: The HTML body has none or less than 5% obfuscated text.

factors.name: HTML Font
factors.title: Your email body includes font that is not following best practices of readability, size, and contrast.
factors.solution: Try to use natural font sizes and easily readable color contrasts for you text. Your message has been flagged as using too large a font or HTML font color similar or identical to the background.
factors.passing_description: The HTML font is readable and of normal size.

factors.name: HTML Tags
factors.title: Your email body includes HTML tags that are not following best practices.
factors.solution: Your message has been flagged as having unbalanced HTML head or body tags. Audit your HTML and fix any improperly nested tags.
factors.passing_description: The HTML body is composed of properply closed and nested tags.

factors.name: HTML Elements
factors.title: Your email includes improper HTML elements.
factors.solution: Audit your HTML and fix any deprecated or non-standard HTML elements. Your message has been flagged with over 40% HTML elements that are non-standard.
factors.passing_description: The HTML body is composed of standard and supported HTML elements.

factors.name: Embedded HTML Elements
factors.title: Your email is loading an external non-standard object.
factors.solution: Remove any HTML iframe elements or embedded plugins. Your message has been flagged as having a HTML IFRAME tag with SRC URI or an embedded plugin object.
factors.passing_description: The HTML is not loading any external elements, such as an iframe.

factors.name: Link URL Sizes
factors.title: Your email body includes URLs that are too long and may be flagged by spam filters.
factors.passing_description: The HTML body includes links with URLs that are of normal length.

factors.name: HTML Body Link Count
factors.title: Your message body contains more than the recommended amount of HTML links.
factors.passing_description: The HTML body has fewer links than commonly found in spam messages.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Publishing a DKIM key will will reduce the likelihood of your messages being blocked or ending up in the spam folder. It will also prevent spoofing by adding a digital signature to your email headers.
aspects.message: Your DKIM record is not setup using best practices.

factors.name: Existing DKIM Signature
factors.title: Your email was not signed with DKIM.
factors.solution:
Generate a Public DKIM Key for your domain. This needs to be done with the applications you are using to send emails and/or your mail server.
Add the Public Key to your Domain's DKIM DNS records.
Enable DKIM signing from your Email Service Provider and mail server / application if applicable.

Existing DKIM Signature Header:
Version: 1
Domain: sendgrid.net
Algorithm: rsa-sha256
Algorithm_type: relaxed/relaxed
Selector: smtpapi

NOTE: Gmail requires a DKIM key of 1024 bits or longer. Other Email Service Providers may also have their own size requirements.
factors.passing_description: The email is signed with DKIM, whether or not it is a valid signature.

factors.name: Verified DKIM Signature
factors.title: Your email is not properly authenticated with DKIM.
factors.solution:
Update your DNS records with the correct public DKIM key.
The public key, represented by the p= tag, on your DKIM DNS record is unverified or revoked.

Existing DKIM Signature Header:
Version: 1
Domain: sendgrid.net
Algorithm: rsa-sha256
Algorithm_type: relaxed/relaxed
Selector: smtpapi
factors.passing_description: The email is signed with a valid DKIM signature, whether or not it is from the correct sender domain.

factors.name: DKIM Signature Sender Domain
factors.title: The DKIM signature is not from the author's or envelope-from domain.
factors.solution:
Generate the domain key for your domain and publish a DKIM key from the tool that you used to send this email. Make sure that DKIM signing is turned on for your domain through your Email Service Provider.

Existing DKIM Signature Header:
Version: 1
Domain: sendgrid.net
Algorithm: rsa-sha256
Algorithm_type: relaxed/relaxed
Selector: smtpapi



NOTE: It may be signed with your Email Service Provider's default DKIM domain key instead.
factors.passing_description: The email is signed with a valid DKIM signature, and from either the correct author or envelope-from domain.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Spam complaints are the #1 factor that will hurt your email deliverability. Including an easy unsubscribe mechanism effectively helps prevent these spam complaints. Email Service Providers and spam filters also view it favorably when they make inboxing decisions.
aspects.message: Your email is missing the List-Unsubscribe header.

factors.name: List-Unsubscribe Header
factors.title: There is no List-Unsubscribe header.
factors.solution: Using an email tool that allows you to alter email headers, add the List-Unsubscribe header with the appropriate mailto and/or link for receivers to unsubscribe with.
factors.passing_description: The email includes a List-Unsubscribe header.

aspects.why_is_it_important: A valid SPF record will prevent spammers from sending spam from your domain.

factors.name: Existing SPF DNS Record
factors.title: You don't have a SPF Record published.
factors.solution: Publish a SPF record that includes all the tools you are currently using to send emails from your domain.
factors.passing_description: There is a SPF DNS record published for the "from" domain.

factors.name: Duplicate SPF DNS Records
factors.title: You have multiple SPF records published.
factors.solution:
Sign into your domain hosting provider.
Go to the DNS settings for your domain.
Merge both SPF record(s) into a single SPF record. This can be done by deleting the secondary SPF record and combining them into 1 record.
Update your SPF record to ensure it includes all applications that are sending emails from your domain.

Existing DNS Records:
gmail.com. 231 IN TXT v=spf1 redirect=_spf.google.com
factors.passing_description: There are no duplicate SPF DNS records for the "from" domain.

factors.name: SPF Authorization
factors.title: You're not authorized to send emails from your domain.
factors.solution:
Sign into your domain hosting provider.
Go to the DNS settings for your domain.
Update your SPF record to ensure it includes all applications that are sending emails from your domain.

Existing SPF header attributes:
Status: pass
Message: sendgrid.net: 149.72.131.227 is authorized to use 'bounces+24653094-eac9-test-palani=test.mailgenius.com@sendgrid.net' in 'mfrom' identity (mechanism 'ip4:149.72.0.0/16' matched)
Receiver: p-pm-inbound02c-aws-useast1c
Identity: mailfrom
Envelope-from: bounces+24653094-eac9-test-palani=test.mailgenius.com@sendgrid.net
Helo: wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net
Client-ip: 149.72.131.227


NOTE: Depending on what tools you use to send emails, some emails may have multiple Received-SPF headers and authentication lookups. It is important that they all pass, but the first Received-SPF header is considered the primary trace field and is used by Email Service Providers to verify the email.
factors.passing_description: The sender is authorized to send emails from the domain.

factors.name: SPF ?all Mechanism
factors.title: The SPF Record for your domain has a neutral policy.
factors.solution:
Sign into your domain hosting provider.
Go to the DNS settings for your domain.
Update your SPF record to use ~all instead of ?all.

Existing DNS Records:
gmail.com. 231 IN TXT v=spf1 redirect=_spf.google.com
factors.passing_description: The SPF DNS record does not include the ?all mechanism.

factors.name: SPF ptr Mechanism
factors.title: Remove the "ptr" mechanism from your SPF record.
factors.solution:
Sign into your domain hosting provider.
Go to the DNS settings for your domain.
Remove the ptr mechanism from your SPF record.

Existing DNS Records:
gmail.com. 231 IN TXT v=spf1 redirect=_spf.google.com
factors.passing_description: The SPF DNS record does not include the ptr mechanism.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Certain domain suffixes are less likely to reach the inbox.
aspects.message: Your domain uses a trustworthy suffix!

factors.name: Domain Suffix
factors.title: Your domain is using a suffix, com, that is more correlated to common spammer suffixes.
factors.solution:
If possible, try to send emails from a domain that uses one of the following most trustworthy suffixes: com, co, net, org, edu, gov

This should be considered on a case by case basis. For example, if the email campaign you are starting is to a contact list that is familiar with your domain this may not be a concern.

NOTE: These domain suffixes can also be used in combination with a country top level domain. In these cases, a suffix of co.uk would be considered very trustworthy.
factors.passing_description: The "from" domain has a trustworthy suffix.

aspects.why_is_it_important: The younger your domain is, the more difficult it is to attain a great domain reputation.

factors.name: Domain Age
factors.title: Your domain: gmail.com, is 9662 days old.
factors.solution: You can buy a mature domain and setup up your outbound email process around it. This of course has it's own set of required efforts and risk. Or you could wait and warm up your current domain, but this could take months.
factors.passing_description: The age of the "from" domain is mature.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Having broken links in your email body can cause Email Service Providers to mark your message as spam.
aspects.message: Your email has no broken links!

factors.name: HTML Body Broken Links
factors.title: Your email body includes broken links.
factors.solution:
Fix or remove any broken links.

Broken href sources:


NOTE: This test shows results at the time of when the email was sent and not necessarily the current state of the links.

Some links may be flagged as 'broken' due to timing out (set to 8 seconds) when trying to make a connection. The links are being tested via a server request rather than emulating a user click in the browser, so there may be slight differences in behavior. The request does allow for redirects and does account for missing resources.
factors.passing_description: Requests for all links in the HTML body return a successful HTTP response code.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Certain blacklists can have a severe affect on the ability to reach the inbox. We have aggregated a list of ones known to be meaningful.
aspects.message: Your domain is not listed on any significant blacklists!

factors.name: Domain Blacklists
factors.title: Your domain is listed on 0 significant blacklist(s). This test does not necessarily take specific whitelists into consideration.
factors.solution:
Many blacklists allow you to make a removal request. Visit these URLs to read about and potentially make a removal request for your domain.


NOTE: If you know you are on this whitelist you can likely ignore this failure, but double checking can't hurt. It is also showing results at the time of when the test was run and not necessarily the current state of the domain's blacklists.
factors.passing_description: The "from" domain is not listed on any impactful blacklists.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Using shortened URLs to track receiver behavior can cause spam filters to flag your email.
aspects.message: You are not using any dangerous short URLs!

factors.name: Short URLs
factors.title: Your email body includes potentially dangerous short URLs.
factors.solution:
Remove the common short URLs from your message body.

URLs:
factors.passing_description: The HTML body does not include many of the common dangerous short URLs.

aspects.why_is_it_important: The subject line is parsed and analyzed by spam filters and can cause your email to miss the inbox.
aspects.message: Your subject line is following anti-spam best practices!

factors.name: Subject Line Gappy Text
factors.title: Your subject includes formatting that is commonly flagged at spam.
factors.solution: Remove any ALL CAPS words/phrases/sentences and any g.a.p-t.e.x.t formatting.
factors.passing_description: The subject line is not formatted using gappy text.

factors.name: Subject Line Spam Language
factors.title: Your subject includes language that is commonly flagged at spam.
factors.solution: Remove any language like 'as seen', 'buy', 'buying', 'your family', dollar amounts, dieting, drugs, dieting, and sexual content.
factors.passing_description: The subject line does not contain many of the commpan spam phrases.

factors.name: Subject Line Obfuscation
factors.title: Your subject includes obfuscated words.
factors.solution: Use normal text formatting absent of obfuscation so that Email Service Providers do not flag it as an attempt to hide text.
factors.passing_description: The subject line formatting is clear and not obfuscated.

factors.name: To Address in Subject Line
factors.title: Your subject includes the local part of the email address you are sending to.
factors.solution: Avoid including the sent to email address in your subject. Your subject was flagged having the Local part of the To: address.
factors.passing_description: The subejct line does not include the sent to email address.

factors.name: Subject Line Irregular Characters
factors.title: Your subject includes raw irregular characters.
factors.solution: Remove any 8-bit characters or characters that are not correctly MIME (Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions) encoded. These characters may flag your email as being sent from an untrustworthy email software.
factors.passing_description: The subject line is composed of legitimate and accepted characters.

aspects.why_is_it_important: Email Service Providers like Gmail, Yahoo, etc. may block emails coming from a mail server that does not have Reverse DNS in place.
aspects.message: Your mail server Reverse DNS is properly configured.

factors.name: Mail Server Reverse DNS
factors.title: The Mail Server IP that your email was received from does not have a Reverse DNS pointer record that resolves to the correct received from Mail Server domain.
factors.solution:
The sending Mail Server IP (Received From IP) must match the IP of the domain in the Pointer (PTR) record, also known as the Reverse DNS record. The PTR record verifies that the sending domain is associated with that sending Mail Server IP.

Your Mail Server IP 149.72.131.227 does not resolve to your Mail Server domain wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net. This is typically setup by your Email Service or Hosting Provider, but if you have set up your own dedicated mail server and IP address the burden may be on the sender to setup their own reverse DNS. If you are using an Email Service or Hosting Provider then you should contact and work with them to set up the PTR DNS record.

If you are using your own mail server and dedicated IP and have full access to your DNS settings, then you may need to correctly setup a DNS zone and PTR DNS record.
First you may need to configure a DNS zone in a specific format for reverse DNS. Reverse the IP address after dropping the last octet and then append .in-addr.arpa. This will result in a zone domain of 131.72.149.in-addr.arpa.

Then add a PTR record with a name of 227, the last number in your IP address. The hostname should be the mail server domain that you want the IP address to resolve to, e.g. myownmailserver.example.com

Now you should have the DNS record:
227.131.72.149.in-addr.arpa. IN PTR myownmailserver.example.com


Existing DNS Records:
227.131.72.149.in-addr.arpa. 299 IN PTR wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net.
Received From Mail Server Header:
from wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net (wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net [149.72.131.227]) (using TLSv1.2 with cipher ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256 (128/128 bits)) (No client certificate requested) by p-pm-inbound02c-aws-useast1c.inbound.postmarkapp.com (Postfix) with ESMTPS id 312C5404E1D for ; Tue, 25 Jan 2022 05:10:26 +0000 (UTC)
factors.passing_description: The Mail Server IP that the email was received from has a rDNS PTR record that resolves to the received from Mail Server domain.

factors.name: Mail Server and HELO Alignment
factors.title: The Reverse DNS of your Mail Server IP does not match the HELO.
factors.solution:
Certain Mail Servers may block your email if the sending server IP Reverse DNS does not match the HELO. You should contact and work with your Email Service or Hosting Provider to set this up correctly.

HELO Domain: wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net

HELO Client IP: 149.72.131.227


The HELO does not match the sending Mail Server that this message was received from. Received From Mail Server header:
Received From Domain: wrqvvpzp.outbound-mail.sendgrid.net

Received From IP: 149.72.131.227
factors.passing_description: The Mail Server IP rDNS matches the HELO client-ip.

aspects.why_is_it_important: SpamAssassin is a widely used anti-spam platform and is a valuble proxy when gauging whether or not your email will be flagged as spam by major Email Service Providers.
aspects.message: Your SpamAssassin score is safely below the spam threshold.

factors.name: SpamAssassin
factors.title: SpamAssassin has assigned a score of -2.4 to your email.
factors.solution:
SpamAssassin flagged this email as Spam: No
With a Spam Score of: -2.4

SpamAssassin parses emails and assigns it a score starting from 0.0. This means scores above 0.0 are more like a spam message and scores below 0.0 are less so. SpamAssassin will mark an email as spam at a score of 5.0.
